Mc2Bfs6RQQCWwR6joQdzzg.text: This is Alan Yau's third Busaba Eathai, and follows the same success as the other two. It is a good place to go to for a quick decent meal - perfect for busy people who are always on the go. It is decked out with large wooden communal tables and always filled with people. The menu is a range of noodles, curries, vegetable and rice dishes. I come here for a big bowl of their noodle soup. They do a Tom yam variety which is tangy and hot. The food comes in generous portions, and the prices are very agreeable. Staff, though friendly, can be almost to hasty at times, making one feel rushed. But that's very much an Asian quality, and I don't mind it.

SvJp9Mo5RPfAy2mAEleTWg.text: This branch is nicely hidden away, just off Oxford Street, following wagamaa seating, sharing tables with others, it has a lot more atmoshphere than Wagamama's with the smell of incense burning as you wait to be seated and the lit candles floating in the water by the entrance. The food is good, finding your usual thai currys meat and fish, and my favourite drink, guava collins. Food normally comes speedily. I have eaten here on numerous occassions and seem to ecperience the same staff mistakes each time! the large tables seem to through some of the workers. You can expect them trying to offer you dishes that you have not ordered. I have also on a couple of occassions found receipt and change set down infront of me before i have even paid! they are trying to give me food and money! Although the staff are friendly, when going to place an order I have been advised against what i wanted to eat, to the point of being pushy! A great place to fill up, not really a place to linger in though. Can get very busy in the evenings.

d5eNRW5wE3vhxP3HfQDLeQ.text: When ordering, I opted for the Green Curry Rice with Grilled Chicken, with some Thai Roti on the side (I love bread products - sue me). This invoked the ire of our waitress. 'You know it's spicy?' she enquired in a cute little patronising tone. Gee, thanks. Don't you realise that nowadays, at least in London, Thai is the new Indian? I guarantee you that everyone in that restaurant would have eaten Thai before. But anyway, she then went on to tell me I shouldn't order the roti because my meal would be 'dry'. I ignored her because nothing annoys me more than being policed on my food choices by staff. My Chinese foodie friend, who ordered Pad Thai, was spared from any critiquing about her menu choices. As the restaurant started filling up to the brim around us, our food arrived. And my lord, it almost made up for the crappy service we were being subjected to. My 'dry dish' was in fact swimming in a beautiful green curry sauce, with a rice tower and darkly grilled chicken. The chicken was cooked perfectly; juicy inside, but with a crunchy skin, just how I like it. The rice seemed almost to be coated lightly in curry sauce, but without being turned into a swimming mess. And the sauce, well the sauce itself was a delight. Not one of those curry sauces which make your eyes water from the first bite, the flavour built up from pleasant and 'not spicy at all' to having a bit more kick near the end. It was delicious. The Thai Roti were puffed up, doughy and greasy - perfect for using to scoop flavour-filled rice into ones mouth. My friends Pad Thai appeared to be everything a Pad Thai should be. There were no complaints from my friend, and she ate her entire plate, which is unusual for this slow (super slow) eater. It is worth noting that when our portions first came out we both thought they looked dainty and fairly small portioned, but in fact,we could scarce cram our last mouthfuls in). Once done, and feeling pleasantly hazy in that post-food way, it was not long until we were dropped down to earth with a unceremonious bill. We tried to leave it, as we still had drinks to finish, but the waitress came back over and asked how we were going to pay, leaving us to be forced out with drinks half drunk. Overall, Busaba has pissed me off a bit. It is not hard to run a upmarket fast food restaurant whilst still having good service. I may be banging on about Wagamamas, but that is because both these places have the same idea. Exotic food, served fast, (but not McDonalds fast), communal seating and a certain speed of eating expected. However, I have never felt rushed or harassed by staff at a Wagamamas. I have been on dates to Wagamamas, and ate with friends, where we have lingered a little longer, and the staff have never made us feel pressured, even with people queuing out the door. Busaba on the other hand, made us feel unwelcome right from the start. This is a huge shame, because the food at Busaba was so good, and reasonably priced. I would go back to another branch of Basaba's, but I will not bother going back to this one, which is a shame.

OiLGWlkGA_ddxXHTiI6vDg.text: I love all the Busaba Eatthais in London - the original one on Wardour Street, the one here on Bird Street, then there is also one on Store Street near Tottenham Court Road (which has a table you can book for up to 22 people for parties) The squid is amazing, as are the chili prawn fried rice and the chicken curries. The roti is soo good when you dip into the curry as well. Great atmosphere, affordable and top notch food.

tPNfbF2Tg8-DsB9yi9JA3Q.text: I was dragged here by a couple of lovely friends who love it and I have to say I agree with them! It is a little bit Wagamama stylee, as in different groups of people sit around the same tables. Sometimes it annoys me in Wagamama, but I quite liked it here. The food was really nice, they accidentally gave us more than what we ordered and didn't charge us, oops I think they deserve an extra star for that though! Like pigs, we ordered way more than what we could eat, but it was only because everything was so tempting! It was nice because we shared each other's food and that worked really well because we got to taste quite a bit of the menu. I love thai curry anyway, but it was yummy here, as was the squid! Yum

NGcMUnuNw_-K2orHnI8BGg.text: I have a friend who used to live in Thailand and HE even said that this is the best thai food in London. I might not know thai food as well as him, but I still thought this place was AMAZING! the second I walked in i was overcome with the delicious smells of candles and spices. my mouth was watering instantly. and tears were brought to my eyes.The family style seating brings an element of comfort to the setting, and when they bring ALL your food out at once it gives it a feeling of a home cooked meal (well not at MY home, but SOMEONE'S home..) I can't remember the names of the stuff we ordered b/c he ordered for us, but there was a papaya salad and a prawn shrimp and these chickeny things that were wrapped in palm leaves and something called jungle curry.  Thank god he ordered b/c I looked at the menu and EVERYTHING looked delicious, so I don't think i would have been able to make any decisions.I think I saw that they are opening up another one in Hoxton and you can bet that I am going there a lot.

u3nkH9X7BKfXtPOMgA6cvw.text: A solid dining experience- people say this place is like a thai wagammamas- no it's better. More relaxed. Less hurried. Solid food quality...and on the whole friendly staff. On the one occassion they messed up a business lunch I had organised there they gave me a hefty discount for my next group visit.  I also use the take away service for when I am too lazy to cook at home.

zPTxG9pBQ_W2yPBFjBmvlQ.text: The Busaba chain is one of my favourite casual places to eat in London. The food is amazing, the staff are very "cool". You really cannot linger over your food here but its alot of fun. the juices are good, the food tastes authentic, its fresh, its good and its pretty mid-range. Its pizza express prices. the decor is lovely, the only shame is the Queue ...but if people are willing to wait to be seated for 20-30 minutes you know the food has got to be good! I dont like wagamamas coz it feels too much like a cafateria but this place is amazing!

LUzv-YRLZKqY64lMXelFJQ.text: This place is great, albeit a tad on the touristy side. It's off of Oxford St, so it's to be expected. The room is filled with large square communal tables and you get seated wherever there is availability. The server was friendly and came by pretty quick to take our orders and bring us water. Since they didn't have Pad See Ew, I order the Pad Thai with green mangoes and crab meat. The food came out on a large plate looking and smelling delicious. The taste did not disappoint! I've eaten at a lot of Thai places in SF and NY and this dish rivaled their best! The noodles were cooked well and very flavorful. The crab and green mango were great additions and enhanced the original dish. The two other noodle plates my friends ordered were also really tasty. The only disappointing dish was my other friend's noodle soup dish. The bland soup came in a tiny bowl and barely had any seafood on it. My recommendation - order the noodle dishes!

k9CToDUSuGA-_MuCxNo23Q.text: Authentic Thai cuisine is the specialty at the restaurant that offers noodles, beef and seafood dishes.

BiMlpZuytcY0HYDWqLtKsg.text: All the restaurants in this chain are superb. Remains my firm favourite. Ate here recently and had the Massuman (typo I think!) Duck Curry with Sticky rice and my favourite Thai Calamari on the side. Great food, great ambience and great service. Well deserved 5 stars!

HHbIQ4ePSB4PlvxwTc8HiQ.text: This restaurant has taken on the wagamama concept of dining, applied it to Japanese food and improved it drastically. The communal tables found in Wagamama are present here but it is not too noisy which makes a change from Wagamama. The minimalist, slick design of the restuarant gives the impression that it will be a expensive. In fact prices are very similar to Wagamama's and the food will not disappoint. The curries were all very flavourful and each had their own unique taste. Staff are also very courteous and service is very quick. A perfect place to go to before hitting the town at night!

cJ_MSU7xL1Ge24xjPFVcAQ.text: Shopping around Bond Street station is fun but finding a place for a bite can be a little harder. Especially when you're looking for something that won't leave a mark on the wallet. Luckily for me, London-Eating came to my rescue and recommended me a place. Nestled discreetly at the back of Selfridges comes a saviour, Busaba Eathai. Busaba doesn't take reservations, which can be bad but good for random shoppers who fancy taking a break. I've been coming here occasionally and I like it. Good food at reasonable prices, just don't expect authenticity with all their dishes. Here are a few of what I've tried. Pandan chicken with garlic and coriander root wrapped in pandan leaf £5.5This is some tight as wrapping of the pandan leaf. It took us quite an effort to open it but what you get as a reward is some juicy tasty chicken pieces. The pandan flavour seems to have gotten lost in the process though. Sen Chan Pad Thai £7.40Rice noodles with prawn peanut egg green mango and crabmeatThis was a tad greasy but otherwise enjoyable as well. Ginger and honey tea served with cashew and coconut cookie £2.80This I get every time I'm here. Real Ginger strips that have been added to give that kick at the back of the throat followed by the soothing honey in the hot cup of tea. They may not be the best and most authentic but given the location and scarcity of other cheap eats around, this is a good option.

rnAcUYwYEEhInR0_VcVoNA.text: Service was not good, the server just kept forgetting or did not know what she was doing - it was quite frustrating.  Plus asking for recommendations from her was just a waste because she did not really care to engage or help - almost a wonder why she is serving at a restaurant - she might as well been working at a fast food chain.  Food however was pretty solid.  I will give them kudos for being able to figure out how to make shared tables work well - and still give parties room and privacy.  Definitely a bit loud.  Calamari was a bit overblown IMO but I know fellow yelpers disagree.  I guess I am just used to it prepared differently.  Noodles were delicious!

3u7Cx0bbAq7NsmChOQziVA.text: Delicious food, lots of cool and interesting dishes. Trendy but cozy vibe, and it's big so for sorry about waiting too long for a tad, Also, good prices by London Standards (£10 for a main dish). I'd be back any day I'm craving something Asian.

j7m5a2pK2T2PdajTXnh-pw.text: The food here is delicious, assuming you can get seated to get at it! We waited in line (5 of us) for almost an hour and as there is no seating you just stand there patiently. That would have been fine if it was just a long line, but since it is communal seating they kept taking two people and the line must have cycled through twice before they seated us. Again, this could have been understood if they at least looked apologetic but my queries were rebuffed with disdain, not a good way to build customer loyalty!However, for the price, the food is worth a trip. The calamari is a great pick, fresh and crunchy with a bit of a bite from the chilli. The coconut rice was perfectly cooked, just on the right side of al dente and sweet without being overwhelmingly so. I had some sort of chilli beef dish which was full of flavour. I would have preferred more sauce for the simple reason that it was so delicious I would have kept eating it with rice all night. The acidity of the home made lemonade added a nice counterbalance to the richness of the sauce.Overall, I'll go back in a small group of 2-3 but it's not worth the aggravation of trying to land a larger party.

CV9a_9bSm2NSYomHjRP5xw.text: We were taking our final sips of a cold latte at the Costa on Wigmore St (opp. Levant) when a friend popped by and insisted on going to Busaba. I thought it would be a little bit of a walk, but within minutes we were in the restaurant. OK, so I hadn't heard of the Bird Street location. The place seemed distinctly large or I might have been suffering from a spatial illusion stroke. After being greeted with a fairly warm welcome, we were seated in the communal style tables, which I quite love.The food was very average. The chicken satay was abominable; chicken was rubbery, and the peanut sauce was anemic. Moment of Nirvana :--- You CAN go wrong with chicken satay!... so it wasn't just me, my fellow consumers didn't venture as near as more than a bite. The chicken satay should definitely go off the menu. Green curry; very average. Although I distinctly remember my licking my fingers after a thai curry at Busaba (Wardour St) a year ago. Service is prompt, but not friendly. Overall, this one would be hard to recommend.

kTDAsmsQBN8NkgjCkYvP9Q.text: Great ambiance. Simple decor, shared tables but its just seems to work.Always a queue. I hate waiting but its always worth the wait. and the queues moves pretty fast.Calamari is a must try. I always have one for myself. Wash it down with warm sake - heaven!Never a disappointment on any dishes. Should make trips to try EVERYTHINGThinking about the food is already making me feel hungry.

e_9mTA9GdlPLBNc9-GvFwQ.text: Tasty tasty tasty Thai food with a twist! This branch has a great atmosphere, a fantastic aroma and mouth watering food! This place is big enough to feed your whole family, also cheap enough to feed your whole family. I recommend the Pad Thai and battered prawns!This eatery gets a huge thumbs up!

ZX7OI4oSUuVENpctt9wkaQ.text: It's modern city life with a hint of the East. I appreciate the therapeutic atmosphere! It's warm, energetic, the calm water features, the candles and the lemon grass incense that fills the room  (you can even smell the incense as you walk up towards the entrance).  A bit of warning: Do plan ahead as it does get busy during the evenings especially on weekends and being waited on takes ages! It does take awhile till you get your bill so do ask for it when you have almost finished your meal, that way you can just up and pay for it.I usually order the Thai green curry with coconut rice or grilled duck with coconut rice. I'd say there is more curry then the rice, the portions of the coconut rice is not enough and it is slightly pricey. The curry is rich and I do love the marinated duck.If you are planning for a romantic meal, I suggest you go during quiet times; like early afternoon to avoid the loud combustion (unless you are use to the busy life). Also do take note that you do end up sharing a table with other people (so avoiding eye contact with strangers is slightly difficult). This place is good for gatherings and large groups.

Rr9KzvQXpuMe3joqRL8B_A.text: This place is great for a buzzing bite right in the centre of Soho, on Berwick Street. On a Friday or Saturday night, expect huge queues and a little bit of a wait but how can you resist that smell!During the summer it's nice to sit at the window for a proper Thai lunch and watch passers by, the windows are usually open in the summer and it really feels like you're in the middle of the most happening part of town.Many a celeb has also eaten at Busaba with the theatre district just a hope and a skip away.With alcohol, expect to spend around £20 per person, if you really want a slap-up meal. This place is well worth the visit though, once you're in, the modern surroundings, clinking of plates and cutlery, chitter-chatter and hypnotising smell is enough to win you over for sure...

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom

GiNsGxNDIcEEQEsUz8AG7w.text: I was meeting my parents in Mayfair, they were flustered driving without a Tom Tom in London's labyrinthine set of streets. They proposed La Tasca, I scoffed and reliably informed them that for the same price they could eat great quality, low fuss food in a restaurant sweetly jasmine scented. So we landed at Busaba Eat Thai tucked behind Selfridges, rather less busy than her Wardour Street sister but no less delicious. London restaurateur Alan Yau (the man who brought us Yauachta, Hakkasan and Wagamama) secured private equity investment of £21.5m to transform his Busaba Eathai restaurant into a chain. The flagship Soho restaurant, which opened in 1999, comprises of large square, communal tables serving a menu of authentic Thai food. Chicken wrapped in pandan leaves, creamy green curry, perfectly seasoned pad thai, the list goes on and on. Easily the best value, high quality food in town, only lacking on intimacy due to the communal nature of the tables and lack of advance bookings for smaller groups. Look, even my mother agrees!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom

2N59G3kMUkv9gxWqXOx78Q.text: For photos, please go to chopstix2steaknives.blog…  Shopping around Bond Street station is fun but finding a place for a bite can be a little harder. Especially when you're looking for something that won't leave a mark on the wallet. Luckily for me, London-Eating came to my rescue and recommended me a place. Nestled discreetly at the back of Selfridges comes a saviour, Busaba Eathai. Busaba doesn't take reservations, which can be bad but good for random shoppers who fancy taking a break. I've been coming here occasionally and I like it. Good food at reasonable prices, just don't expect authenticity with all their dishes. Here are a few of what I've tried. Pandan chicken with garlic and coriander root wrapped in pandan leaf £5.5 This is some tight as wrapping of the pandan leaf. It took us quite an effort to open it but what you get as a reward is some juicy tasty chicken pieces. The pandan flavour seems to have gotten lost in the process though. Sen Chan Pad Thai £7.40Rice noodles with prawn peanut egg green mango and crabmeat This was a tad greasy but otherwise enjoyable as well. Ginger and honey tea served with cashew and coconut cookie £2.80 This I get every time I'm here. Real Ginger strips that have been added to give that kick at the back of the throat followed by the soothing honey in the hot cup of tea. They may not be the best and most authentic but given the location and scarcity of other cheap eats around, this is a good option.

7fOn3AvqybtKRz6HtamiqA.text: Here's my problem, I work upstairs from this fantastic eatery, and day in day out, I suffer from a chronic Pavlovian response, by the assault of Lemongrass and Jasmine wafting through the air as I try to scurry past without becoming weak at the knees. A problem no?For comparisons sake, I was always a fan of Wagamamas, but I tended to find myself going straight back to the Katsu Curry time after time, (if I couldn't see enough to make me eat outside the box). Here at Busaba's, I have complete faith that I can move around the menu and be totally stoked at what ever I chose, (but always with a side of Peppercorn Calamari). We had a farewell lunch there for a workmate, and for 9 people all with starters and a main and at least one drink, we came in around £130, so the boss was even happy to pay....I'm giving in to my senses

oFe6RofuITJXvcu8PY1BxA.text: This is the best branch of B.E - quieter and calmer.Great if you are in a rush or not.Chicken green curry is good as is the coconut rice.Why no desserts though?The quality incense they burn in the doorway is a very nice touch.Just wish the seating was a bit more comfy and not all communal.

8pWj62cSGq5nXih67dMO1w.text: Wowza, this place sure seems to be all the rage. Each and every time I set up a meeting with someone from 'round these parts, Busaba Eathai is suggested without fail.  My feelings? Sure, it's fine ... I guess. It's definitely not bad ... Really, it's fine. It's fine. Fine, ok?    Fine .. if that's what everyone wants ... I guess. (If you could see my face right now, you'd see scrunched up eyebrows, lips pursed off to one side and shoulders raised in defense ...in case one of the many 4 and 5 star reviewers come at me in a rage...) Maybe I'm spoiled to amazing thai food from living in the Northwest, (p.s. I love you Portland,) but nothing I've had here (on my 4 visits, mind you) has blown me away. I've yet to feel the spice kick from any dish, even when I've specifically asked for them to "turn up the heat." But unlike others, I really dig the communal seating arrangements and my service has been beyond speedy each visit. My consensus: safe thai food for the masses. Which, to reiterate, is fine. I'm always down for some crowd pleasing favorites ... I guess.

8MCrqTcrqYGaN1NsK8lLwA.text: After queueing for half an hour in the cold last Thursday night outside busaba Eathai I was expecting fireworks. What I wasn't expecting was to be perched on a bench with a load of strangers but luckily the delicious food managed to outweigh the horrific service and uncomfortable seating arrangement.I had the chicken butternut squash stir-fry with cashew nuts and chili for £5.70 with jasmine rice and a coke. By the time I tipped (which I so shouldn't have for the appalling service) it came to about £13. The food was gorgeous, the chicken melted in my mouth and was perfectly filling. The waiters however threw the orders down at us rudely, and gave us all the wrong meals. Not even asking us once if we were ok, it was almost like a practical joke of how much rudeness can you bear. A lot apparently when the food is this good!

tzJmmqTkdZYdTjHRNDNYgQ.text: Yeah, yeah... it's a chain restaurant, and I'm a chain restaurant snob.  Avoid them like the plague usually.  But the food here is reeeeally good and reasonably priced.  I have to say, I'm not a fan of communal seating or waiting in a long queue, both of which you'll find at most of this restaurant's locations.  But I find that this specific location is much more accessible.  Shhh, don't tell too many people, please.

0Kp1wnJBU4BnjKnUSv303A.text: Busaba is a pretty nifty kind of place. I am partial to a spot of Thai cuisine and this place delivers the goods to an exceptional standard. The food is awesome the location and service is not so hot.The layout and decor of the restaurant is pretty swanky. The table are big square communal ones, much like an upmarket cafeteria, this works well if your in a twosome or lucky enough to get a table where everyone is friendly. However, this being London, the chances of that are slim, and in this particular venue, people seem more interested in thier Blackberry than the social going ons around them. Large group meals don't work so well here as your not allowed to book and the chance of getting a whole free square table is unlikely. They also offer window seating where you can sit and watch the world go by, well thats the idea, however this window looks onto a grey wall. Its ok if you have a good imagination.Busaba is very much you eat you leave, which is fine for a working woman or a man on a mission but please do not go here expecting to take your time over a meal. You will be harrassed by the staff who ask if you would like anything else on an avaerage of 5 minutes. "Yes ok, we get the message". The staff are pleasent, and I believe just doing there job as they are probably told more covers = more tips = get as many people in and out as possible. Unlike the Wardour St branch, I have never seen this restaurant full and it has a much more business like feel to it.All that aside the food is outstanding, I recommend the Thai Green Curry or Sen Chun Phad Thai both are delicious and reasonably priced. I believe the curry is just under £8 and the Phad Thai £11, you would be hard pushed to spend alot of money here £20 can easily cover your food and drink. May I also suggest, for those with a small appetite or on a budget, a side of Thai Calamari and Jasmine Rice, so simple and less than £5 and plenty of food. In fact, alot of the side dishes match the mains. I would urge any good foodie to try this place just bare in mind you won't be hanging around for long.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom

o1uInzse160nHOsYEUcEmg.text: A great place to get a quick filling meal if you are out shopping on Oxford Street or staying in one of the nearby hotels.  The food is very good - spicy, not bland, as one would expect from a good Thai establishment.  You can't go wrong with the green curry which is better than my local restaurant at home.  There may be a line at 7pm, but it moves fast and the service is quick.  The only minus is the flavored ice tea which comes in a very small cup priced at L3 - ripoff!  But otherwise you can't go wrong here.  For single travelers there is also nice counter seating at the large window where you can watch the street go by.

ttdixN5YvOjnEIuYaAoUhg.text: Good and sometimes inventive thai without frills. Share u table, order and eat fast and get out of there. Not a place to bring a date but to share with friends. No matter what u ask, order a squid as side. No regrets, and quite good value for money (£20 tops)

_Y11HoFonOtVspQO0ZmASg.text: This is a very good place for Thai food.  Their Thai calamari is excellent - portion wise and quality.  The pad thai was the first one I had in London that I really enjoyed.  I never had lemongrass tea before either.  It is a nice calming tea.  The communal seating area can be a little crowded, but the warm decor of the place makes up for it.  It can also get really busy like a giant queue out the door at 9pm on a Friday evening.  To say it is popular is an understatement.

0nVFh4Yt2PpIPyr_9xw5yw.text: Very good as always but they need to slow down when they serving the food, we ordered 3 starter and 3 main and all came in one shot, so the main was nearly cold when we finished the starter.They have to change just the "Fast Food" attitude, the rest it's impeccable.

p5MRRbHrH-Hz9zRtwBRH-A.text: We were shopping at Selfridges during "the" sale, which obviously made us famish!  Headed over to Busaba for lunch.  The 3 of us shared a table w/ 4 other people.  Initially, I wasn't sure if it would be too difficult to have a conversation.   We were fine.  We ordered:- Pad Thai- Green Curry Chicken- Jungle Chicken- jasmine rice- coconut riceThe pad thai was nice.  Not too sweet, nor too sour - just right.  Jungle chicken was really nice with the aubergine/eggplant.  My personal favorite was the green curry - nice and tastey.  Coconut rice definitely was flavorful.Would recommend going - but just be aware that you'll probable be sharing a table!Cheers!

gOpCNnZ1m22GLztQmoLHlw.text: I really really really liked this place!! to the extent that I was actually there the night after this check in too! Really busy and quite noisey but it had its own vibe which was nice. The food was tremendous and they also served some really nice ginger tea. I had the squid, broccoli and salmon teriyaki which was really nice. Don't judge me, I run miles and miles and miles every week, I gotta eat too!!How refreshing to stumble across a place that didn't look like much from the outside but was unreal on the inside! Definitely will be back.

iSXadOpXHsgIxUqY3nce-g.text: Food good Wait staff horrible ...can't get anyone.. Everyone says ok but then never return ... Roll their eyes n huff at you... Too busy they don't care... I mean why add a "tip" on your bill for wait staff?? It's a waste... Food is good but their attitude is horrible ... They don't care... They're a chain and your cattle ... Order all at once cause you won't see them again FYI

0K7gyvGsCyUTAChMCjfiAA.text: I think I was more impressed with Busaba the first few times I came here but I've since realized that while it is still a very decent place to catch some Thai in central London, it's nothing amazing or out of this world, really. I am sitting here right now as I am writing the review. This is real time stuff!Well, it was. I am now finished the review a little over a week later. The Sen Chan Pad Thai is very good, the hot and sour soup is OK, and the chargrilled chicken is so-so. There are better Thai places in the area but this has decent decor and is positively inexpensive. Not horrible. Is that compelling?

sCZWyfTkPLDpyqvGpqglxQ.text: Visited a couple of years ago and remember really enjoying the food, happen to be passing by so thought i would do a revisit...Had to wait anout 20mins for a table around 1pm.. we were seated on their usual shared seating type table... the waiter eventually brought us our menus... and returned after more then 10mins to take our order...Good ambiance and you can see the chefs hard at work in the kitchen...Had the calamari which was good... the phad thai... which was extremely oily and asked for a red chicken curry which they did not have but the waiter suggested the jungle curry which did not come with rice ao we ordered that as extra... the jungle  curry was really disappoiting and the meat did not have the best of tastes... overall left with a really unsatisfied  heavy unhealthy taste in my mouth...and when considering how much we paid was definitely not worth it by any standard..  will not return... kind of sad as the food was really good last time i came...To top it off it was a busy lunch time so service was poor as well...

PV-s3_bwDiXB9jiTgcgxaA.text: For one of those informal, mix it up type of places where you share bench seats and big tables, this place is still really stylish. Great lighting - low enough to be complimentary and mood enhancing, but good enough to see what you're eating.And what you're eating is pretty impressive, considering BE is a chain. I've been to one of the other branches in Soho and the food didn't compare with this. This is really decent cooking. Not perfect but good enough to find yourself thinking about it the next day and planning a return visit.Thai calamari (why oh why they felt the need to use 'calamari' I'll never know - squid would have been fine, after all, it's not a Thai/Greek restaurant) was good but a little over-cooked. Mango & chilli salad was fab - fresh, lime zesty and tangy with enough chilli to wake up the senses but not overpower them.Satay chicken was seriously good. The thigh meat was incredibly succulent and moist - much tastier than breast in my opinion - and cooked to perfection. The lamb curry (similar to a Massaman) was to die for. Th lamb was delicate and perfectly tender, next to big chunks of potato in a rich, creamy sauce that had a gentle kick. Sticky rice was way too sticky - think they'd overdone it - but underneath the curry sauce, it got away with it.Another visit very soon I suspect.

AtacZZU0ko7zDMjSC0RVXw.text: The place is lively but the Thai is okay. Not the best Thai I've had and I have had a lot in the U.S. The pad Thai was nothing to die for but the chili beef and rice was very good. Their mocktails were interesting! May not got there again unless the food improves.

o13M_-Jx2ZAuCzXzuYTEpw.text: A good option for Thai food from this small London chain.  The other I've sampled is on Store Street, and attracts basically the same review.Food well prepared, sensible portion sizes, service generally good, prices reasonable.Be aware seating is typically "communal" (shared tables)

w4ridOBRYMmupIzE01y96Q.text: Tasty Thai food!Pros... The food is well seasoned and flavoursome. (spicy)The classic dishes are, Thai green curry and pad Thai, loving there style of calamari.The drinks are lovely especially the Guava Bellini.   (small in size but packs a punch).The Cons... Sharing a big table with various other diners . ( stop looking at me) lolI must admit over the years they had more of a wide range menu, but the menu has been limited to the various classic dishes. One of the drinks they used to offer was Cherry bollen soda, love it! Has been removed.( Not happy. )Overall it is one of my spots to go to in west-end after a long day shopping, to catch up with my friends and enjoy some tasty dishes.

opM0gbysrkB6bhxiciCnDA.text: Very good and authentic Pad Thai. Chicken satay is excellent. Service is always consistently outstanding.

NeTWyp0QM2mZejsyBFtJdQ.text: Meh... quite a standard "fast food" type of restaurant. Wagamamas style where you share a big table with strangers, and you have quick meals. Thai noodles and curry dishes at around £7-8, and starters around £4-5. Nothing really special in my mind. I had the tom yam talay, expecting a very fiery and sour tom yam soup that is clear. Instead, I got a coconut cloudy soup base, with just a hint of sourness, and no spiciness at all. Major disappointment. I ordered the chicken satay as well. Chicken satay is typically thin strips of meat on a stick that has been grilled. Busaba Eathai's satay were big chunks of breast meat. Definitely not authentic at all - and it ruins the taste of satay as its not about the meat itself, but about the marinade flavours and the smokiness from the grill, plus the meat used is normally fatter than lean breast meat. Overall - go here if you're just looking to fill your belly while shopping Oxford Street, and craving for some Thai food. The London Insiderlondon-insider.co.uk

PY-rSum-YPOEVosHujVNGw.text: Always happily surprised by Busaba. Trendy, attractive interior decorationPlenty of choices - originial yet not too sophisticated thai foodGreat portion sizes (option to ask for a doggy bag if you have left overs)Good serviceI guess I have been lucky because I never experienced a line.I take one star off for the communal tables which are great for conviviality but not too much if you want something more intimate.In a nutshell: more 5 stars than 4 really. Wish 4.5 were an option

garfSXrFi6CzSr_q0wAuIQ.text: My go-to Thai place in central London. The quality is consistent..ly delicious. They do the basic pad thai well but I prefer the twist the original, pad thai jay, for the extra dose of veggies. The curries are also quite nice.This place is always busy and it's clever that they have the shared table set up to move the line faster. It's probably not ideal if you're on a date but I'm usually here with a small group of girlfriends so sharing a table is not an issue.For the price, this place can't be beat!

p4uff5--g_FKABMS6hsATw.text: Try the guava collins - so often drinks that bill themselves as guava bear only a faint resemblance; not this one! lovely flavoursome blend of guava with a hint of lime and underpinned by a touch of coconut. A great way to set you up for the menu to follow.Our welcome was warm, service great, and meal gloriously tasty. Try the fish stew, and the grilled veggie side was lovely also. Thumbs up all roun!

Qis5k5rJpveVjzp9oJHmPg.text: Great food, excellent prices. The chicken wings are the best in town. It is the best place for a quick lunch after shopping on oxford street

elFOdpPskPIU6lFjjRxKIA.text: Hmmm...mixed feelings about Busaba after my last trip. First time round (at the Wardour St. branch), I would have definitely given it four stars and possibly even five based on flavour, decor and value for money, but I was quite disappointed with this trip. It was Saturday night and pretty packed so perhaps I should let them away with the slip ups but we were served raw chicken which is hard to forgive. It was the chicken satay starter and it was very pink and cold on the inside! Apparently, the size of the chicken chunks have changed so the cooks must have mixed up the timing, but still...The dish was discounted from the bill but it would have taken a little more than that for me to forget about the incident. There was also a faff with drinks being added to the bill that we hadn't ordered but I guess that can happen with those big shared tables. I am a big fan of the big shared tables and the decor in general. The food (when cooked) is very tasty too, my ginger beef main contested to this fact. Those eating with me also thoroughly enjoyed their curries (red lamb and green chicken) and chargrilled beef.I will return soon to see if to update this review and be able to give it more stars (here's hoping!) or if things go badly, reduce to a sad one star...c*

r96LzVSMWLyKDn5PHpB-iQ.text: Good "western thai" restaurant, with affordable prices and good location. The place is qutie big with a lot of big square tables in the middle and some seats next to the window...you might end up sharing the table with other groups, that sometimes is quite funny...My favourite stuff are the fried prawns (delicious), the traditional pad thai (very big portion) and the meat fillet in soy sauce (forgot the name, but it is very good). Wine list is okayish, not very prestigious wines but possible to order a glass only of decent wine for a limited price.Not 5 stars because of the queue at the door that can be quite long over the weekend and the impossibility to book. Staff is nice (many of which are Italians!)

wGptKVVd55PaniQSciAk6g.text: I would not mind having this Thai chain in the States.  It is what it is - fusion Thai for the masses - but what it is ain't bad.  Seating is communal and the noise level is high, making for a vibrant buzzing atmosphere.  Service is quick and efficient.The food is pretty good.  I tried the red mullet jungle curry with coconut tip, green peppercorn, and chilli, as well as the geng gari gari, a chicken curry with new potato and cucumber relish.  The jungle curry was a bit disappointing, spicy but skimping on depth of flavor.  The chicken curry was much better, with lovely curry-infused chunks of chicken and potato.I don't know that it's worth waiting in line for, and if £8 curries that don't even come with rice pass for cheap eats in London...well, yikes, sorry mates.That said the food is perfectly adequate and the vibe is fun.  I can see how this place might become a neighborhood staple.  I just wouldn't go out of my way to return.

d16wO9UkIqkH_w36UuuEpA.text: Let's take it from the top. Queue: 20 people. That's normal. And they've thought about it. There's a loooong corridor where you stand. It's decorated, and kept warm, so waiting is not unpleasant at all. Time to sit down: 5 min. I was surprised! Mind you, it's very easy to get a seat if you're 2 people, it's the 3+ that starts to be a challenge. Still, they give you menus while you're in the queue to speed things up, and watching the floating candles and flowers keeps you zen anyway. Time to order: 5min. Waiters are quite eager... Time for food to come: 20min. Started getting bored, but then all the food came at once! They don't bother with starters and things, everything comes at the same time and you dive in. YUM! Food is delicious, service generally quick if not always fluent in english, and the ambience lovely, especially if, like me, you are trying to escape valentine's coupledom dominion of cheesiness. The great big square tables of 10 people each form a lovely space on which we can lay out many dishes, and talk to each other and eavesdrop on other conversations. The wooden decor and low-hanging just-bright-enough lamps cast a flattering glow on the food and patrons. The food is delicious (you have GOT to try the prawns under the "sides" heading) and I had to order me more. Originally I was scared as 90% of the dishes are either vegetarian (boring) or spicy (uh oh...). I went with spicy, preferring to risk a burn rather than forego meat, and was pleasantly surprised! Yes, it was spicy, but it was perfectly tolerable even for my low tolerance palate. So I was happy. My plan is to head back there with a group of 10 friends and take over an entire table to ourselves, having a crazy dinner on an otherwise boring evening. Tip: It's on Oxford Street, just past Bond Street station, behind the GAP. Keep walking north, it's on the left hand side.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. The floating candles and flowers at the entrance
Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom

zN4oDPY7PauuG-DTautJrA.text: The food and atmosphere were both fantastic. The calamari and san chan pad Thai were both the best I've tasted by far

mpgqsDsjHNJWjjNd_rtetg.text: Decent place, decent food, and average service. Went for a quick lunch, and I quite enjoyed my drunken noodles. It wasn't cooked in the standard way, but I didn't mind the creativity and twist. Seafood in it was pretty fresh and the seasoning was flavourful. Service was okay but slow. We had to ask for tap water three times before it was brought. Food came on time, though. No major hiccups, but could have been better. Ambience was the usual as with its other stores. Spacious but given shared tables, may not be for anything intimate.

Ii_hAS9MtBDVDNMuRV4snA.text: We're still quite close to this Busaba Eathai and we continue to order from here regularly. They've never mixed up a to-go order or an order when we've eaten in. The food has always been absolutely delicious. It's even hard to choose a favourite! The Bangkok King Prawn dish is amazing. It's a dry yellow curry that goes really well with rice and has incredible flavour. The Tom Yam Gong soup is also bursting with lemongrass and curry flavours. And their classic pad thai is the best I've ever had. I usually don't like pad thai because I find most of them too dry and too peanut-y. This one is moist and has nice hints of lemongrass and citrus. Amaaaaazing. I would always order the phad phak. It's just a small side of vegetables but the sauce they cook it in is seriously out of this world. It's sweet but savoury and compliments the veggies very well. It think the only thing I've had from here that wasn't crazy about was the chilli prawn fried rice. It didn't stand out to me. But who cares! That leaves so many more options! yayayayaya

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Pad Thai jay
Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Phad phak
Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Soybean and aubergine stir fry

Igm7iy2R8WYvOXYE6rhbXw.text: The food just okay. .But the service was very bad. .We already order and the waitress already repeat our order. But,at the end the waitress never input 2 of our order. .So disappointed with the bad services and will never come back again. .

spw4g5b3SUpHdy8zSFWaoA.text: When I was in town for the weekend I always found myself in the neighborhood so would stop by for pad thai, massaman curry, fish cakes, etc. Prices are reasonable and ambience was good until my last visit when I think my waiter was coming down from a drug-induced high. He looked like he needed another hit of coke: sweating, shaking, paranoid-looking.

_WscNejA1IvUlV4RHn0Lnw.text: Progressively getting worse over the last couple of years. Last time my meal was delivered in reverse; main, then entree, prawn crackers and then drink.Today we had two booked tables (separate bills) on a not too busy day. We ordered with the Manager on a table of 9. There was a mixture of menu and express menu items, but it took 50 minutes for the last order to arrive. The menu items (4) came first at 40 minutes, and then (4) express items 5 minutes later. My express menu meal came a further 5 minutes later. It was supposed to be Crispy Duck Noodles. What I got looked more like noodle vomit. The duck was warm, but the noodles looked like they had sat in cold water for too long and had started to break down. The noodles were cold and soggy with sparsely dispersed small chunks of hot duck meat. I sent it back to the kitchen where it was heated up, and returned to me. Google the meal and compare it to what I received.No apology for the tardy service. Half the mains were served before the entree arrived. Drinks took a long time to arrive. Water jugs took even longer to be replaced. Prawn cracks that were ordered but never arrived (not charged to the bill). Yet they still wanted to charge for my meal?!? And a service charge!!!I couldn't give anything lower than 1 star, which is a shame cos I'd give no stars at all!

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Crispy Duck Noodle...  or Cold Noodle Vomit with small Duck chunks...

dkt6FhA5depY1xIPW6RP1Q.text: Recommended by a friend, we decided to try this chain. I loved the ambience & seating arrangements of the place. We came at an earlier dinner time, so it wasn't too crowded. We ordered the calamari, pad thai, and fish curry dishes. We aren't into spicy so got mild for both mains. We got the pad thai and fish curry first. Mmm. They use thin noodles for the pad thai which was awesome. So delicious and not drenched in sauce like many Asian fusion places I've tried. The fish curry was also very delicious, so soft and well paired with the curry. They brought the calamari as a side rather than as an app for some reason, but it was also quite delicious - a decently large portion, too. Top notch Thai food, a bit on the expensive side, though I'd love to come back here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Calamari
Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Fish curry
Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Pad Thai

_wBrh0uxryNHY4F7CAQGlg.text: Not even close to the best Thai food Ive had in London, much less anywhere else. I came here for lunch after some shopping on Oxford, and was so looking forward to some curry. I ordered the Mussaman Duck with a side of coconut rice. The curry, which is typically meant to lean toward peanutty tasted more like satay (not to say it was bad, just not what I thought), and the coconut rice was overcooked - crunchy and unpleasant. Service left something to be desired - waitress seemed nervous and made scarce appearances. Wont likely come here again.

6m9gc9u-QkF_hN6xxf3ttQ.text: Decent Thai food with lots of options. We didn't realize it's a chain, but it was still good. You knew it was a good choice because all the business people came for lunch and looked like regulars. I also liked the communal tables- gave it a fun atmosphere.

cLdj0HjoXNsIIEgmFw1Ymw.text: At our first day in the city we got a little hungry and asked the first random person on the street for any recommendation. It turned out she was a food blogger and recommended Busaba. We had the lunch specials and were satisfied all the way. Tasty staters, a small main course assembled with some lemongrass tea in a very welcoming atmosphere. Perfect place for a light snack or probably even a full meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Early afternoon hours, not very busy but very comfortable atmosphere.

xrXvD_4UznYK-1ATBB_0Bw.text: thai food in london? yes why not? ordered:*pad thai- 8.50 YUM. definitely a hit to this yelpers eye and tummy! when it was bought out i didn't have very much expectations but i loved it! *songkhla red curry w/beef- 10.90 - surprisingly really good!!! i totally recommend this dish if you are a fan of curry. i totally licked this bowl clean. it was SOOOO yummy in my tummy. there's not a lot of beef FYI.*ginger beef-9.50 this is a very small portion made with very little beef. i felt like there was more mushrooms if anything. but overall the ginger beef was okay. nothing super special in my POV*rice set green curry w/ grilled chicken- 9.90 this dish wasn't bad however because the red curry was so good that i can't say i would wanna recommend this. *jasmine rice- 2.50 which really is a small bowl of riceoverall, portion size is quite small. as you can tell we ordered 4 dishes to do a family style between the 4 of us. at least the hubby and i felt a little hungry still. so i would probably suggest that you don't do family style. everyone should just eat their own dish. i wasn't a huge fan of the table layout. imagine a picnic table type. so you'll probably be sharing a table with others. tips:*separate male and female restrooms. female restroom has tons of stalls.*located on a corner.*indoor seating only.*street parking*this is a chain restaurant.*does not have thai ice coffee or thai ice tea*free wifi*serves alcohol*cash and credit cards accepted*they have gluten free options*10% gratuity is is added to the bill*they have a wall where you can hang your jackets and put your strollers*they make you put on an umbrella bag if you have a wet umbrella.

photos.caption: Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Pad thai
Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Steam rice
Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom. Menu

tJwBa8wiag4Jev7OZljrWQ.text: After reading other reviews, I was very excited to try their food.  Unfortunately, their pad Thai was rather greasy without much flavor.  In addition, I dined solo at the restaurant and felt ignored during most of my dining experience.

VDxuYpCpfVBz_DFl0eBB2Q.text: I normally would've given this place 4-5 stars, but I went twice in one week and the inconsistency is terrible. My first meal was sooo good! Probably the best thai place I've eaten in London. I swear all ethnic food is a bit rubbish! But I was so glad I stumbled upon this spot between Oxford street shopping. The first time, I decided to get a noodle dish; my favorite is pad thai or pad see ew, but I saw they had this starred version - which included crab meat. Obviously, it was clear to me to splurge. I went home and was pleasantly surprised that the noodle was a good consistencies, the spice was a good level and had plenty of shrimp and tofu! (not so much crab meat, but that was expected)My second encounter was last night, I was famished from shopping. I was looking forward to eating this in the comfort of my home tonight so I decided to order more (and for 1 - lonely, I know). I got the regular pad thai and green curry + rice. The pad thai was the biggest disappointment, it wasn't spicy at all! Complete 180 from last week's dish. I was scrambling to see if I had any hot sauce in the hotel cuz it was soooo bland. Secondly, the green curry didn't have much substance. It had very little corn and peas - I'm used to the regular bamboo shoots, bell peppers version. It was bad, but definitely did not give enough rice for how thick the curry was. The spice level was medium, but it definitely lacked vegetables or something to add to the dish. All in all, I'm pretty disappointed that I wasted stomach space for this. Definitely try something new next time.

UTLyhoTacFixKtvHzpyISQ.text: For some reason I've always expected this place to be a bit on the pricey side, which is something I don't really associate with Thai food... well it's not, in fact its reasonably priced. (Reasonable... £28 for two mains and two drinks, which I appreciate you can get cheaper but in the area it's not bad)There's a lot of choice in this small area (next to selfridges) but if your after quick and tasty I'd recommend this place. The layout is communal eating so if it's busy, you'll be sharing a table with others, unless you have a group big enough for your own table (probably around 8). It's got a ethnic feel to the decorations inside with lots of dark wood and Thai statues around. There is a good selection of food on the menu covering all the traditional favourites plus a few "specials". We went for the pad thai and the north Thai Laksa - that I wouldn't normally associate with Thai but it was actually really good!.There's an abundance of staff that are always on the look out for how they can help and therefore all very friendly. I should mention this place is a chain and in their other stores we haven't had such a good experience.

fQZ4QAl_eVF-EHzI9-GDiA.text: I'm a big fan of Busaba, it is slightly on the pricey side for the food.  But it tastes good and is well presented.  There are lots of options on the menu for people that don't eat meat and don't like their food too spicy.The restaurant is nicely lit with candles and incense is burning giving it a nice calm atmosphere and an authentic feel.  The tables are communal style and it's likely that you will have to share with other diners, but usually you can still have a audible conversation.The staff were friendly and attentive and ensured we had enough tap water during our visit. I'm quiet excited that there is now an app and it offers loyalty points - yay my favourite.

ldrr5WzDgJhO4TTsfI4SPA.text: Standard Thai food. I don't particularly enjoy sharing tables awkwardly with strangers, but you keep going back for the food! For a casual meal, it's a safe bet.

p5xO_kjekYyM8o1Jo2GmcA.text: I'm not really a big fan of the communal tables (unless you're planning to go with a group). The food was very greasy, and we had to ask for tap water about three times before getting it. We had a lovely waiter, but the overall experience was just OK.

JlSLYlpK0U2hTSu_-LMO9Q.text: This place focuses on looks more than the food. At least by stir fry beef was tougher than I am and the sauce in my wife's stir fry prawns left a lot to be desired. I left hungry, not willing to order something more from the overpriced-compared-to-the-quality menu. And while I get that not everyone need to serve cider, the fact that the waiter does not even know what it is or that she did not bother to ask if we wanted more water with a clearly empty bottle on the table, the service was negatively surprising and left an overall bad taste.

GyDRjGnos8uuiX1NwMT5Lg.text: My boyfriend and I have been traveling in England for about a week, and so far, the food has been fantastic- until we came here. I was craving Asian food and the tube was slammed so we opted to come here bc it was close. Bad idea. The service is HORRIBLE. You have to yell to talk to the person next to you. ALWAYS asking for water, wtf! I shouldn't have to ask for water 4x and the last time I asked for water and the check as well, the waiter I guess decided to not bring it bc I had asked for the check as well. If you're going to do the communal table, then they need to break into sections. There are way too many people for the service to be this shitty. The food wasn't even ok. The saving grace was the tom yum soup. This spot is definitely not worth it and I regret not attempting the crowd for something else.

TLnN7aZD_QHyvSCIrhrICw.text: Nice environment, decent pad thai, will try again next time~

Photo of Busaba St Christopher's Place - Marylebone, London, United Kingdom
